body:
As you might have heard, [Python 2 is EOL in about 11 months](https://pythonclock.org/). I wonder what is the roadmap of Cython regarding Python 2 support, because [most core scientific Python projects have already explicited theirs](https://python3statement.org/).

In particular, I guess dropping Python 2 support would help fixing [some cygdb bugs](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aopen+cygdb) which in my opinion make using Cython a bit more painful than it should.

comment_data.body:
We don't have a specific roadmap, but given that we're a low-level
dependency we do have a history of supporting Python versions long after
EOL. We are working on changing the default language level to be 3 with the
next release.

This is a good question for the list.

(It would be good to fix the cygdb bugs regardless, only fixing them on
Python 3 would be reasonable.)

On Thu, Jan 17, 2019 at 10:14 AM Juan Luis Cano Rodríguez <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> As you might have heard, Python 2 is EOL in about 11 months
> <https://pythonclock.org/>. I wonder what is the roadmap of Cython
> regarding Python 2 support, because most core scientific Python projects
> have already explicited theirs <https://python3statement.org/>.
>
> In particular, I guess dropping Python 2 support would help fixing some
> cygdb bugs
> <https://github.com/cython/cython/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aopen+cygdb>
> which in my opinion make using Cython a bit more painful than it should.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2800>, or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAdqgW-ODxCHQgMo0mOuzoluoTQRnocUks5vED8SgaJpZM4aEwjw>
> .
>

I agree with what Robert said, also regarding a discussion on the list.

To add a bit to that, CPython 3.8 is [scheduled](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/) for October 2019, and that seems like the point of decision to me. I think some users might appreciate it if we could get a Cython release out then that supports it as well as Python 2.7, so that they could continue to use that release as long as they feel like it. But I would personally not mind having 0.29 be the last Py2 compatible release, or 3.0. It's not like what's been released will magically start failing on January 1st next year. And I probably wouldn't object to making a bug fix release for that last Py2 release series if someone backports a fix that we make in a future version.

I think the main question is really: should we still add Py3.8 to the current list of supported Py2+ versions or not.

I don't see a future Cython release support Python 3.9+ and still carry around Py2.7 cruft.

As discussed on the cython-users mailing list, Cython 3.0 will still provide support for Python 2.7, both for running the compiler in it and for building and using the generated extension modules.

This is meant to ease the upgrade path for users who want to port to Cython 3.0 but cannot yet drop support for Python 2.7 on their side.

Support for Python 2.7 and Python < 3.4 (or < 3.5, TBD) will be removed in Cython 3.1. Both Cython 3.0 and 3.1 are expected to be released in the course of 2019.

Given that Py3.4 is now out of maintenance, and that the test suite takes excessively long to run in Py3.4, I strongly favour removing also the support for Py3.4 in Cython 3.1, which will then only target Py3.5 and later.

+1

On Wed, Mar 27, 2019 at 7:16 PM Stefan Behnel <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Given that Py3.4 is now out of maintenance, and that the test suite takes
> excessively long to run in Py3.4, I strongly favour removing also the
> support for Py3.4 in Cython 3.1, which will then only target Py3.5 and
> later.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2800#issuecomment-477289060>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAdqgTBwQk3Fn-haOf9UpFvhZr1CSYEoks5va7VqgaJpZM4aEwjw>
> .
>

+1 for announcing these plans/policies in developer documentation (perhaps a project roadmap). It would make it easier for new folk to contribute to the project. I suspect downstream projects would also appreciate knowing Cython's version support plans.
I want to volunteer on this issue
I don't think it's something for right now. There will be more changes along the way for Cython 3.0, and Py2 support will only be removed afterwards. Better keep the risk of collisions low then.
sure maybe after cython 3.0 release?

Update: we missed 2019, and will hardly make 2020 for the Cython 3.0/1 releases.

Since Python 3.5 is also officially out of maintenance now, I think it's best to remove all support for Python < 3.6 and only support the then maintained 3.[6789] in the Cython 3.1 release. [That means we can](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html) start using f-string formatting in our code base, rely on ordered dicts and on UTF-8 as Windows filesystem encoding, will no longer need backwards compatibility shims for async code and `typing`, … Oh, golden times… :)
Python 3.6 has now [reached](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0494/#id14) EOL as well.

> `typing`, … Oh, golden times… :)

No need to say that we all want to have `typing` in cython sooo much!

This issue is now almost 4 years old, Python 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5 have been [end-of-life](https://endoflife.date/python) for a long time:

- Python 2.7: Security support ended 2 years and 10 months ago (01 Jan 2020)
- Python 3.4: Security support ended 3 years and 8 months ago (18 Mar 2019)
- Python 3.5: Security support ended 2 years ago (13 Sep 2020)

The last time the Python version requirement [was raised](https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/8c490265b8c2b23e8680068c9d18210e5f82c8e7) was 4 years ago, in november 2018. At that moment, Python 2.6 and 3.3 support was removed.

So would it be time to consider dropping Python 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5 already before the 3.0 release? I have no idea how far away it is, but the list of features missing out on is growing, the testing and CI matrices for minor version support keep growing and the percentage of users still using those versions is getting smaller.

Of course the 0.29.x release series can keep support. I think the intersection of users still using Python 2.7, 3.4 or 3.5 _and_ benefiting from the latest improvements of Cython 3.0 is quite small.

@scoder just commented in #5130:
> We will remove Python 2.7 support in Cython 3.1. That's the main feature of that future release.

That plan hasn't changed for a long time, and it doesn't look like it will. Still, I understand the sentiment (of @EwoutH), not least because that plan was made when Cython 3 was still scheduled for 2019 - three years later, I think reality has overtaken the utility of keeping Python 2.7 support in Cython 3; with every passing month it is more and more just dead weight for an (almost) empty set of users.

At the same time, there are only 1-2 remaining blockers (with PRs +/- ready to be merged) for 3.0, so if an end is in sight, then of course it's better just to push it over the finish line as-is.

Sidenote: with adding CI for 3.12 alpha, Cython will support 10(!) separate python versions released over a span of ~15 years - a monumental feat. 🤯

My view is:
* I think the plan of "release Cython 3 with Python " support, then drop it shortly afterwards" still makes sense now. Even if it was probably made with the expectation of Cython 3 being a little earlier.
* I don't hugely care about supporting Python 3.4/3.5 personally - I'm not quite sure who's using those. But I don't think they're causing us too much pain at the moment.
on cython 3.0 there should be 2.7 + 3.6/3.7+ only. python 3.4 and 3.5 do not have much user. even if, they can use older versions.

Whatever the Python devs say about their support intentions, here are the PyPI download starts, averaged over the last month:
```
2.6 :         12.8 / day (  0.0%)
2.7 :      36806.6 / day (  4.2%)
2.8 :          1.0 / day (  4.2%)
3.1 :          8.5 / day (  4.3%)
3.2 :         15.5 / day (  4.3%)
3.3 :          5.4 / day (  4.3%)
3.4 :        133.7 / day (  4.3%)
3.5 :       7317.9 / day (  5.1%)
3.6 :      48094.7 / day ( 10.7%)
3.7 :     327190.8 / day ( 48.4%)
3.8 :     199755.2 / day ( 71.5%)
3.9 :      94715.5 / day ( 82.4%)
3.10:     131179.3 / day ( 97.6%)
3.11:       7568.3 / day ( 98.4%)
3.12:         53.6 / day ( 98.4%)
null:      13590.5 / day (100.0%)
```
Both 2.7 and 3.6 still seem rather relevant – dropping everything <= Py3.6 would cut off 11% of the daily downloads. Even 3.5 does not seem entirely negligible to me, even though it's probably small enough to let users stick with Cython < 3.0.

I think it's reasonable to keep support for Python 2.7 and 3.5+ in Cython 3.0, and remove everything below Py3.6 in Cython 3.1. But I'm open to also drop Py3.5 support in Cython 3.0, if there's somewhat of a reason. (Sorry for the edits.)

Here's how it's changed:

![cython](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/202157603-0319d5da-b35b-4d7a-905e-b70362b4fea1.png)

For comparison, it's not that unusual when compared to other packages that have already dropped 2.7: 

* https://hugovk.github.io/pypi-tools/charts

The top downloaded package urllib3 had 4.91% downloads for Python 2.7 last month, and [are dropping 2.7 now](https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/stable/v2-roadmap.html#optimized-for-python-3-6) (the alpha just came out).

> Both 2.7 and 3.6 still seem rather relevant – dropping everything <= Py3.6 would cut off 11% of the daily downloads.

I would strongly argue to keep 3.6 in, even if it's end-of-life. It's a way more modern version than 2.7. So I would suggest keeping this discussion about dropping 3.5 and lower, which means dropping 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5. Moving to Python 3 allows to drop a large amount of redundant code, and 3.4 and 3.5 are not used that much. Also, Python 3.6 is the lowest version [cibuildwheel](https://github.com/pypa/cibuildwheel) supports.

That brings me to the following point again:

> Of course the 0.29.x release series can keep support. I think the intersection of users still using Python 2.7, 3.4 or 3.5 and benefiting from the latest improvements of Cython 3.0 is quite small.

I strongly believe that _intersection_ of users on very old Python versions like 2.7 expecting and using new cython features is very small. There is a very good case to be made for keeping legency support and bugfixes for such a important project as cython, but that's where the 0.29.x maintenance branch is for.

The second question is how close is the 3.0 release? If it's withing a few months, keeping 2.7 in for a tad longer doesn't have that much costs, but if it's more than 6 months away I would say let's drop it now to allow reduced testing, CI and maintenance efforts to speed up development.

> @hugovk: For comparison, it's not that unusual when compared to other packages that have already dropped 2.7:

This is the key point IMO - even numpy, which dropped python 2.7 almost three years ago, still has ~3% downloads for 2.7. Those old machines are still running, but it's really unlikely that this is anything more than keeping the lights on - i.e. almost certainly no active development. 

Anyway, I'm keeping my fingers crossed for 3.0 soon (and have tried to help with reviewing the blocker PRs, to my limited ability at least), then the whole discussion becomes moot. 🙃

rename.to: Remove support for Python 2 and Python 3.3/4

rename.from: Remove support for Python 2 and Python 3.3/4
rename.to: Remove support for Python 2 and Python 3 < 3.6

rename.from: Remove support for Python 2 and Python 3 < 3.6
rename.to: Remove support for Python 2 and Python 3 < 3.6 in Cython 3.1

milestone.description: Remove support for Python 2 and Python < 3.5. Maybe also for Python 3.5, TBD.

title: Remove support for Python 2 and Python 3 < 3.6 in Cython 3.1
